nexttext:
where $\omega = \exp{2\pi i/p}$ is a primitive $p$-th root of
unity and
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="K(a)~{}=~{}\sum_{x\in{\mathbb{F}}}\omega^{{\mbox{\scriptsize\rm Tr}}(x+a/x)}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>K</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo rspace="5.8pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">=</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>𝔽</mi></mrow></munder><msup><mi>ω</mi><mrow><mtext>Tr</mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Recall that under $x^{-i}$ we understand  $x^{p^m-1-i}$, avoiding by
this way a division into $0$.

Kloosterman sums are used for solutions of equations over finite
fields \cite{lid}, in the theory of error correcting codes \cite{lac}, for
studying and constructing of bent and hyperbent functions \cite{ch3,he2} and so
on. Surely, any Kloosterman sum $K(a)$ for a given $a$ can be
found directly computing its value for every element of the field,
but this method requires a large amount of computations, which is
a multiple of the size of the field. Hence more simple methods of
computations of Kloosterman sums are quite interesting. The values of
characteristic $p \in \{2,3\}$ are especially interesting in connection with
the number of $q$-rational points of some elliptic curves \cite{kat,lac,lis,mo1}.
Divisibility of binary Kloosterman sums by numbers $8, 16, \ldots, 256$ and
computations of such sums modulo some numbers was considered in
papers \cite{ch1,ch2,gee,go1,go2,go3,he1,lis,lim,mo2}.
Divisibility of ternary Klosterman sums $K(a)$ by $9$ and by $27$ was
considered in \cite{go2,go3,go4,gee,lis,lim}. Furthermore, in \cite{go2,go3,go4}
a complete characterization of $K(a)$ modulo $9$, $18$ and $27$ was obtained for
any $m$ and $a$.

In the recent papers \cite{ba0,ba1} we provide two algorithms to
find the maximum divisor of $K(a)$ of type $2^k$. Similar results
for the case $p=3$ have been announced in \cite{ba2} and here we
prove these results. In particular, we give a simple test of
divisibility of $K(a)$ by $27$. We suggest also a new recursive
algorithm of finding the largest divisor of $K(a)$ of the type
$3^k$ which needs at every step the limited number of arithmetic
operations in ${\mathbb{F}}$. For the case when $m = g\,h$ we derive the
exact connection between the divisibility by $3^k$ of $K(a)$ in
${\mathbb{F}}_{3^g}$, $a \in {\mathbb{F}}_{3^g}$, and the divisibility by $3^{k'}$ of
$K(a)$ in ${\mathbb{F}}_{3^{gh}}$.

\section{Known results}

In this section we state the known results  about Kloosterman
sums $K(a)$ \cite{lis,mo1} and elliptic curves $E(a)$ \cite{eng,men}
over finite fields ${\mathbb{F}}$ of characteristic $3$. Our interest is the
divisibility of such sums by the maximal possible number of type
$3^k$ (i.e. $3^k$ divides  $K(a)$, but  $3^{k+1}$ does not divide
$K(a)$; in addition, when $K(a) = 0$ we assume that $3^m$  divides $K(a)$,
but $3^{m+1}$ does not divide; recall that $q=3^m=|{\mathbb{F}}|$).

For a given ${\mathbb{F}}$ and any $a \in {\mathbb{F}}^*$ define the elliptic curve $E(a)$
as follows:

a finite abelian group, which can be represented as a direct product
of a cyclic subgroup $G(a)$ of order $3^t$ and a certain subgroup
$H(a)$ of some order $s$ (which is not multiple to $3$): $E(a) = G(a) \times H(a)$,

this way a division into $0$.

Kloosterman sums are used for solutions of equations over finite
fields \cite{lid}, in the theory of error correcting codes \cite{lac}, for
studying and constructing of bent and hyperbent functions \cite{ch3,he2} and so
on. Surely, any Kloosterman sum $K(a)$ for a given $a$ can be
found directly computing its value for every element of the field,
but this method requires a large amount of computations, which is
a multiple of the size of the field. Hence more simple methods of
computations of Kloosterman sums are quite interesting. The values of
characteristic $p \in \{2,3\}$ are especially interesting in connection with
the number of $q$-rational points of some elliptic curves \cite{kat,lac,lis,mo1}.
Divisibility of binary Kloosterman sums by numbers $8, 16, \ldots, 256$ and
computations of such sums modulo some numbers was considered in
papers \cite{ch1,ch2,gee,go1,go2,go3,he1,lis,lim,mo2}.
Divisibility of ternary Klosterman sums $K(a)$ by $9$ and by $27$ was
considered in \cite{go2,go3,go4,gee,lis,lim}. Furthermore, in \cite{go2,go3,go4}
a complete characterization of $K(a)$ modulo $9$, $18$ and $27$ was obtained for
any $m$ and $a$.

In the recent papers \cite{ba0,ba1} we provide two algorithms to
find the maximum divisor of $K(a)$ of type $2^k$. Similar results
for the case $p=3$ have been announced in \cite{ba2} and here we
prove these results. In particular, we give a simple test of
divisibility of $K(a)$ by $27$. We suggest also a new recursive
algorithm of finding the largest divisor of $K(a)$ of the type
$3^k$ which needs at every step the limited number of arithmetic
operations in ${\mathbb{F}}$. For the case when $m = g\,h$ we derive the
exact connection between the divisibility by $3^k$ of $K(a)$ in
${\mathbb{F}}_{3^g}$, $a \in {\mathbb{F}}_{3^g}$, and the divisibility by $3^{k'}$ of
$K(a)$ in ${\mathbb{F}}_{3^{gh}}$.

\section{Known results}

In this section we state the known results  about Kloosterman
sums $K(a)$ \cite{lis,mo1} and elliptic curves $E(a)$ \cite{eng,men}
over finite fields ${\mathbb{F}}$ of characteristic $3$. Our interest is the
divisibility of such sums by the maximal possible number of type
$3^k$ (i.e. $3^k$ divides  $K(a)$, but  $3^{k+1}$ does not divide
$K(a)$; in addition, when $K(a) = 0$ we assume that $3^m$  divides $K(a)$,
but $3^{m+1}$ does not divide; recall that $q=3^m=|{\mathbb{F}}|$).

For a given ${\mathbb{F}}$ and any $a \in {\mathbb{F}}^*$ define the elliptic curve $E(a)$
as follows:

Moisio \cite{mo1} showed that

The set of ${\mathbb{F}}$-rational points of the curve $E(a)$ over ${\mathbb{F}}$ forms
a finite abelian group, which can be represented as a direct product
of a cyclic subgroup $G(a)$ of order $3^t$ and a certain subgroup
$H(a)$ of some order $s$ (which is not multiple to $3$): $E(a) = G(a) \times H(a)$,
such that
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="|E(a)|~{}=~{}3^{t}\cdot s" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><mi>E</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt" stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">=</mo><mrow><msup><mn>3</mn><mi>t</mi></msup><mo>⋅</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where $|A|$ denotes the cardinality of a finite set $A$ (earlier the same
result was obtained in \cite{kat} for the curve $y^2+xy+ay=x^3$). Therefore
a Kloosterman sum $K(a)$ is divisible by $3^t$, if and only if the
number of points of the curve $E(a)$ is divisible by $3^t$. Lisonek \cite{lis}
observed, that $|E(a)|$ is divisible by $3^t$, if and only if
the group $E(a)$ contains an element of order $3^t$.

Since $|E(a)|$ is divisible by $|G(a)|$, which is equal to $3^t$, then
generator elements of $G(a)$ and only these elements are of order
$3^t$.

\section{New results}

We begin with a simple result. It is known \cite{ah1,gee,lim}, that $9$
divides $K(a)$ if and only if $Tr(a) = 0$. In this case $a$ can be
presented as follows: $a = z^{27} - z^9$, where $z \in {\mathbb{F}}$,
and, hence $x_0 = a^{1/3} = z^9 - z^3$ (see (\ref{eq:2.4})). We
found the expression for the next element $x_1$, namely:

prevtext:
Emphasize once more, that similar conditions permit in \cite{go2,go3,go4}
to find all values of $K(a)$ modulo $9$, $18$ and $27$, while the
condition (\ref{eq:3.1}) gives only divisibility of $K(a)$ by $27$.


Similar to the case $p=2$ \cite{ba0,ba1}, we give now also
another algorithm to find the maximal divisor of $K(a)$
of the type $3^t$, which requires at every step  the limited
number of arithmetic operations in ${\mathbb{F}}$.

Let $a \in {\mathbb{F}}^*$ be an arbitrary element and let
$u_1, u_2, \ldots, u_{\ell}$ be a sequence of elements of ${\mathbb{F}}$,
constructed according to the following recurrent relation
(compare with (\ref{eq:2.4})):

nexttext:
Then the following result is valid.

\begin{thm}\label{theo:3.1}
Let $a \in {\mathbb{F}}^*$ and let $u_1, u_2, \ldots, u_{\ell}$ be a sequence of
elements of ${\mathbb{F}}$, which satisfies the recurrent relation (\ref{eq:3.2}),
where the element $u_1$ satisfies (\ref{eq:3.3}) and $(u_1,*) \in E(a)$.
Then there exists an integer $k \leq m$ such that one of the two
following cases takes place:\\
(i) either $u_k=a^{1/3}$, but the all previous elements $u_i$ are not equal to $a^{1/3}$;\\
(ii) or $u_{k+1} = u_{k+1+r}$ for a certain $r$ and the all elements $u_i$ are
different for $i < k + 1 + r$.\\
In the both cases the Kloosterman sum $K(a)$ is divisible by $3^{k}$
and is not divisible by $3^{k+1}$.
\end{thm}

{\indent{\em Proof. \ }}
Let $a \in {\mathbb{F}}^*$ and let $u_1, u_2, \ldots, u_{\ell}$ be a sequence of
elements of ${\mathbb{F}}$, which satisfies the recurrent relation (\ref{eq:3.2}),
where the element $u_1$ satisfies (\ref{eq:3.3}) and the point
$P_1=(u_1,*)$ belongs to $E(a)$.
Assume that $E(a)$ has the order $3^t \cdot s$, where $s$ is prime to $3$.
We have to show that $k=t$.

Denote $P_i=(u_i,*)$. Since $P_1=(u_1,*)$ belongs to $E(a)$, it
follows from the addition operation in the additive abelian group $E(a)$
(Table 2.3 in \cite{eng}) and from (\ref{eq:3.2}), that for $i\geq 2$ all points
$P_i$ belongs to $E(a)$ and $P_i=3^{i-1}P_1$ for $i\geq 2$.

There are only two possibilities: either $P_1 \in G(a)$, or
$P_1 \in E(a)\setminus G(a)$.

First consider the case $P_1\in G(a)$. We claim that the condition (\ref{eq:3.3})
implies that $P_1$ is a generating element of the (cyclic) group $G(a)$.
Indeed, assume that it is not the case. Then it means that there is the point
$Q\in G(a)$ such that $P_1=3\,Q$. Assuming that $Q=(x,*)$ and using the addition
operation in $E(a)$ \cite{eng}, we arrive to the following equation for $x$:
prevtext: where $(u_1,*) \in E(a)$ and

nexttext: As we already mentioned in Section 2, this equation has a solution, if and only if
prevtext:
Then the following result is valid.

\begin{thm}\label{theo:3.1}
Let $a \in {\mathbb{F}}^*$ and let $u_1, u_2, \ldots, u_{\ell}$ be a sequence of
elements of ${\mathbb{F}}$, which satisfies the recurrent relation (\ref{eq:3.2}),
where the element $u_1$ satisfies (\ref{eq:3.3}) and $(u_1,*) \in E(a)$.
Then there exists an integer $k \leq m$ such that one of the two
following cases takes place:\\
(i) either $u_k=a^{1/3}$, but the all previous elements $u_i$ are not equal to $a^{1/3}$;\\
(ii) or $u_{k+1} = u_{k+1+r}$ for a certain $r$ and the all elements $u_i$ are
different for $i < k + 1 + r$.\\
In the both cases the Kloosterman sum $K(a)$ is divisible by $3^{k}$
and is not divisible by $3^{k+1}$.
\end{thm}

{\indent{\em Proof. \ }}
Let $a \in {\mathbb{F}}^*$ and let $u_1, u_2, \ldots, u_{\ell}$ be a sequence of
elements of ${\mathbb{F}}$, which satisfies the recurrent relation (\ref{eq:3.2}),
where the element $u_1$ satisfies (\ref{eq:3.3}) and the point
$P_1=(u_1,*)$ belongs to $E(a)$.
Assume that $E(a)$ has the order $3^t \cdot s$, where $s$ is prime to $3$.
We have to show that $k=t$.

Denote $P_i=(u_i,*)$. Since $P_1=(u_1,*)$ belongs to $E(a)$, it
follows from the addition operation in the additive abelian group $E(a)$
(Table 2.3 in \cite{eng}) and from (\ref{eq:3.2}), that for $i\geq 2$ all points
$P_i$ belongs to $E(a)$ and $P_i=3^{i-1}P_1$ for $i\geq 2$.

There are only two possibilities: either $P_1 \in G(a)$, or
$P_1 \in E(a)\setminus G(a)$.

First consider the case $P_1\in G(a)$. We claim that the condition (\ref{eq:3.3})
implies that $P_1$ is a generating element of the (cyclic) group $G(a)$.
Indeed, assume that it is not the case. Then it means that there is the point
$Q\in G(a)$ such that $P_1=3\,Q$. Assuming that $Q=(x,*)$ and using the addition
operation in $E(a)$ \cite{eng}, we arrive to the following equation for $x$:

nexttext:
that contradicts to (\ref{eq:3.3}). We conclude that $P_1$ is a generating point
of $G(a)$ and, therefore, has the order $3^t$. This means that the point
$P_t=(u_t,*)=3^{t-1}P_1$ is of the order $3$. Since there are exactly two points
in $E(a)$ of the order $3$ \cite{eng}, namely, the points $(a^{1/3}, \pm a^{1/3})$,
it means that for any $i \leq t-1$ we have that $u_i \neq a^{1/3}$. Therefore,
$k=t$ and $K(a)$ is divisible by $3^t$.

Now consider the case when $P_1 \in E(a)\setminus G(a)$. Then the order $d$ of
the point $3^tP_1=(u_{t+1},*)$ divides $s$. The point $d\,P_1$ belongs to
the cyclic group $G(a)$, and it is a generating element, since the equality
$dP_1=3Q$ for some $Q \in E(a)$ implies the equality $P_1=3Q'$, that contradicts
to (\ref{eq:3.3}). Therefore the order of the point $P_1$ is equal to $d\cdot 3^t$
and $K(a)$ is divisible by $3^t$.

Denote by $r$ the least integer, such that
$d$ divides $3^r-1$ or $3^r+1$.  Then we have the following equalities:
\\in the first case

nexttext: and in the second case

in $E(a)$ of the order $3$ \cite{eng}, namely, the points $(a^{1/3}, \pm a^{1/3})$,
it means that for any $i \leq t-1$ we have that $u_i \neq a^{1/3}$. Therefore,
$k=t$ and $K(a)$ is divisible by $3^t$.

Now consider the case when $P_1 \in E(a)\setminus G(a)$. Then the order $d$ of
the point $3^tP_1=(u_{t+1},*)$ divides $s$. The point $d\,P_1$ belongs to

to (\ref{eq:3.3}). Therefore the order of the point $P_1$ is equal to $d\cdot 3^t$
and $K(a)$ is divisible by $3^t$.

In the both cases we obtain, that $u_{t+1} = u_{t+1+r}$ and our sequence
$u_1, u_2, \ldots, u_{\ell}$ becomes
periodic with a period $r$, starting from the elemnt $u_{t+1}$.
\qed

Directly from Theorem \ref{theo:3.1} we obtain the following necessary
and sufficient condition for an element $a \in {\mathbb{F}}^*$ to be a zero of
the Kloosterman sum $K(a)$.

\begin{cor}
Let $a \in {\mathbb{F}}^*$ and $u_1, u_2, \ldots, u_{\ell}$ be a sequence of
elements of ${\mathbb{F}}$ of the order $|{\mathbb{F}}|=3^m$, which satisfies the recurrent relation
(\ref{eq:3.2}), where the element $u_1$ satisfies (\ref{eq:3.3}).
Then  $K(a) = 0$, if and only if $u_m = a^{1/3}$, and
$u_i \neq a^{1/3}$ for all $1 \leq i \leq m-1$.
\end{cor}


\begin{exa}\label{ex:3.1}
Suppose the field ${\mathbb{F}}$ of order $3^5$ is generated by $\phi(x) =
x^5 + x^4 + x^2 + 1$ and its root $\alpha$ is a primitive element
of ${\mathbb{F}}$. Take $a=\alpha^{31}$. Following to Statement \ref{stat:3.1},
present $a$ as $a=z^{27}-z^9$. We find that
$z \in \{\alpha^{16}, \alpha^{106}, \alpha^{231}\}$. The corresponding
possible values of $x_1$ are $\alpha^7, \alpha^{19}$ and
$\alpha^{105}$, respectively.  For all these values
of $z$ the condition (\ref{eq:3.1}) is satisfied. We conclude that
$K(a)$ is divisible by $27$. Choosing $x_1=\alpha^7$ and solving
the cubic equation (\ref{eq:2.4}), we obtain three solutions for
$x_2$, namely, $x_2 \in \{\alpha^{138}, \alpha^{196}, \alpha^{237}\}$.
Choose $x_2=\alpha^{138}$. Then the condition (\ref{eq:2.3})
(with $\xi=x_2$) is not valid:
prevtext:
and, respectively, the following upper bound for the value of Kloosterman
sum $K(a)$ takes place:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex11.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="K(a)~{}\leq~{}3^{m}~{}-~{}3^{k}(2\,r+1)." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>K</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo rspace="5.8pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">≤</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><msup><mn>3</mn><mi>m</mi></msup></mpadded><mo rspace="5.8pt">-</mo><mrow><msup><mn>3</mn><mi>k</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mn>2</mn></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>r</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
\end{rem}

Directly from Theorem \ref{theo:3.1} we obtain the following necessary
and sufficient condition for an element $a \in {\mathbb{F}}^*$ to be a zero of
the Kloosterman sum $K(a)$.

\begin{cor}
Let $a \in {\mathbb{F}}^*$ and $u_1, u_2, \ldots, u_{\ell}$ be a sequence of
elements of ${\mathbb{F}}$ of the order $|{\mathbb{F}}|=3^m$, which satisfies the recurrent relation
(\ref{eq:3.2}), where the element $u_1$ satisfies (\ref{eq:3.3}).
Then  $K(a) = 0$, if and only if $u_m = a^{1/3}$, and
$u_i \neq a^{1/3}$ for all $1 \leq i \leq m-1$.
\end{cor}


\begin{exa}\label{ex:3.1}
Suppose the field ${\mathbb{F}}$ of order $3^5$ is generated by $\phi(x) =
x^5 + x^4 + x^2 + 1$ and its root $\alpha$ is a primitive element
of ${\mathbb{F}}$. Take $a=\alpha^{31}$. Following to Statement \ref{stat:3.1},
present $a$ as $a=z^{27}-z^9$. We find that
$z \in \{\alpha^{16}, \alpha^{106}, \alpha^{231}\}$. The corresponding
possible values of $x_1$ are $\alpha^7, \alpha^{19}$ and
$\alpha^{105}$, respectively.  For all these values
of $z$ the condition (\ref{eq:3.1}) is satisfied. We conclude that
$K(a)$ is divisible by $27$. Choosing $x_1=\alpha^7$ and solving
the cubic equation (\ref{eq:2.4}), we obtain three solutions for
$x_2$, namely, $x_2 \in \{\alpha^{138}, \alpha^{196}, \alpha^{237}\}$.
Choose $x_2=\alpha^{138}$. Then the condition (\ref{eq:2.3})
(with $\xi=x_2$) is not valid:

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex12.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{\mbox{\rm Tr}}\left(\frac{a\sqrt{x_{2}^{3}+x_{2}^{2}-a}}{x_{2}^{3}}\right)~{}%
=~{}{\mbox{\rm Tr}}(\alpha^{202})~{}=~{}1~{}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mtext>Tr</mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msqrt><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></msubsup><mo>+</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>a</mi></mrow></msqrt></mrow><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></msubsup></mfrac><mo rspace="5.8pt">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">=</mo><mrow><mtext>Tr</mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>α</mi><mn>202</mn></msup><mo rspace="5.8pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">=</mo><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><mn>1</mn></mpadded></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

We conclude that $k=3$ (see Theorem \ref{theo:3.1}) and $K(a)$ is divisible
by $3^3$ (here $r=1$). The

\medskip

Assume now that the field ${\mathbb{F}}_q$ of order $q = 3^m$ is embedded into
the field ${\mathbb{F}}_{q^n}$~($n \geq 2$), and $a$ is an element of ${\mathbb{F}}_q^*$.
Recall that
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex15.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{\mbox{\rm Tr}}_{q^{n}\rightarrow q}(x)~{}=~{}x+x^{q}+x^{q^{2}}+\ldots+x^{q^{n%
-1}},~{}~{}x\in{\mathbb{F}}_{q^{n}}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mtext>Tr</mtext><mrow><msup><mi>q</mi><mi>n</mi></msup><mo>→</mo><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo rspace="5.8pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">=</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mi>q</mi></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><msup><mi>q</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></msup><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><msup><mi>q</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></msup></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="9.1pt">,</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>𝔽</mi><msup><mi>q</mi><mi>n</mi></msup></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Denote by $H(a)$ the maximal degree of $3$, which divides
$K(a)$, and by $H_n(a)$ the maximal degree of $3$, which
divides $K_n(a)$. Recall that in the case, when $K(a) = 0$ over
${\mathbb{F}}_q$, where $q=3^m$, we assume that $3^m$ divides $K(a)$, but
$3^{m+1}$ does not divide. There
exists a simple connection between $H(a)$ and $H_n(a)$.

\begin{thm}\label{theo:3.2}
Let $n = 3^h\cdot s$, ~$n \geq 2$,~$s \geq 1$, where $3$ and $s$
are mutually prime, and $a \in {\mathbb{F}}^*_q$. Then
prevtext:
For any elements
$a \in {\mathbb{F}}_q$ and $b \in {\mathbb{F}}_{q^n}$ define
\begin{eqnarray*}
e(a) ~=~\omega^{{\mbox{\scriptsize \rm Tr}}(a)},~~
e_n(b) ~=~\omega^{{\mbox{\scriptsize \rm Tr}}({\mbox{\scriptsize \rm Tr}}_{q^n \rightarrow q}(b))},
\end{eqnarray*}
where $\omega$ is a primitive $3$-th root of unity.
For a given $a \in {\mathbb{F}}_q^*$ it is possible to consider the
following two Kloosterman sums:\\
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex16.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="K(a)~{}=~{}\sum_{x\in{\mathbb{F}}_{q}}e\left(x+\frac{a}{x}\right),~{}~{}~{}K_{%
n}(a)~{}=~{}\sum_{x\in{\mathbb{F}}_{q^{n}}}e_{n}\left(x+\frac{a}{x}\right)." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>K</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo rspace="5.8pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">=</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>𝔽</mi><mi>q</mi></msub></mrow></munder><mrow><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mi>a</mi><mi>x</mi></mfrac></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="12.4pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo rspace="5.8pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">=</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>𝔽</mi><msup><mi>q</mi><mi>n</mi></msup></msub></mrow></munder><mrow><msub><mi>e</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mi>a</mi><mi>x</mi></mfrac></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
Denote by $H(a)$ the maximal degree of $3$, which divides
$K(a)$, and by $H_n(a)$ the maximal degree of $3$, which
divides $K_n(a)$. Recall that in the case, when $K(a) = 0$ over
${\mathbb{F}}_q$, where $q=3^m$, we assume that $3^m$ divides $K(a)$, but
$3^{m+1}$ does not divide. There
exists a simple connection between $H(a)$ and $H_n(a)$.

\begin{thm}\label{theo:3.2}
Let $n = 3^h\cdot s$, ~$n \geq 2$,~$s \geq 1$, where $3$ and $s$
are mutually prime, and $a \in {\mathbb{F}}^*_q$. Then
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex17.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="H_{n}(a)~{}=~{}H(a)~{}+~{}h." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>H</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo rspace="5.8pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>H</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo rspace="5.8pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">+</mo><mi>h</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\end{prop}

{\indent{\em Proof. \ }}
By definition of the trace we have for any element $x \in {\mathbb{F}}_{q}$
\begin{eqnarray*}
{\mbox{\rm Tr}}({\mbox{\rm Tr}}_{q^n \rightarrow q}(x))&=&{\mbox{\rm Tr}}(x+x^q+x^{q^2}+\cdots +x^{q^{n-1}})=\\
&=&{\mbox{\rm Tr}}(x)+{\mbox{\rm Tr}}(x^q)+{\mbox{\rm Tr}}(x^{q^2})+\cdots +{\mbox{\rm Tr}}(x^{q^{n-1}})=\\
&=&n\,{\mbox{\rm Tr}}(x)=\\
&=&\pm\,{\mbox{\rm Tr}}(x),
\end{eqnarray*}
where the last equality follows, since $n$ and $3$ are coprime. Therefore,
${\mbox{\rm Tr}}_{q^n \rightarrow p}(x)=0$ for any $x\in {\mathbb{F}}_q$, if and only if
${\mbox{\rm Tr}}_{q \rightarrow p}(x)=0$. And, since $a, a^{1/3} \in {\mathbb{F}}_q$, then
all solutions of the equation (\ref{eq:2.4}) belong to ${\mathbb{F}}_q$, that gives
the statement.
\qed

\begin{prop}\label{stat:3.2}
Let $n=3$ and $a \in {\mathbb{F}}^*_q$. Then
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex18.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="H_{n}(a)~{}=~{}H(a)." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>H</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo rspace="5.8pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="5.8pt">=</mo><mrow><mi>H</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
\end{prop}

{\indent{\em Proof. \ }}
By definition of the trace we have for any element $x \in {\mathbb{F}}_{q}$
\begin{eqnarray*}
{\mbox{\rm Tr}}({\mbox{\rm Tr}}_{q^n \rightarrow q}(x))&=&{\mbox{\rm Tr}}(x+x^q+x^{q^2}+\cdots +x^{q^{n-1}})=\\
&=&{\mbox{\rm Tr}}(x)+{\mbox{\rm Tr}}(x^q)+{\mbox{\rm Tr}}(x^{q^2})+\cdots +{\mbox{\rm Tr}}(x^{q^{n-1}})=\\
&=&n\,{\mbox{\rm Tr}}(x)=\\
&=&\pm\,{\mbox{\rm Tr}}(x),
\end{eqnarray*}
where the last equality follows, since $n$ and $3$ are coprime. Therefore,
${\mbox{\rm Tr}}_{q^n \rightarrow p}(x)=0$ for any $x\in {\mathbb{F}}_q$, if and only if
${\mbox{\rm Tr}}_{q \rightarrow p}(x)=0$. And, since $a, a^{1/3} \in {\mathbb{F}}_q$, then
all solutions of the equation (\ref{eq:2.4}) belong to ${\mathbb{F}}_q$, that gives
the statement.
\qed

\begin{prop}\label{stat:3.2}
Let $n=3$ and $a \in {\mathbb{F}}^*_q$. Then

nexttext:
Assume that $K(a)$ is divisible by $3^k$. Then it is easy to see
that $K_3(a)$ is divisible by $3^{k+1}$ and is not divisible by
$3^{k+2}$.
\qed


From Theorem \ref{theo:3.2}, recalling that equality $K(a)=0$
over ${\mathbb{F}}_q$ means divisibility of $K(a)$ by $q$, we immediately
obtain the following known result \cite{lim}.

\begin{cor}
Let $a \in {\mathbb{F}}^*_q$ and $n \geq 2$. Then $K_n(a)$ is not equal to zero.
\end{cor}
